text: @ChorusOne Yes, you can sample longer for higher certainty. We provide a default probabilistic bound that exceeds Bitcoin's, and that number of rounds takes ~100ms on our current testnet. This latency can grow a bit as we get nodes distributed across the globe, so we understate by 10x!

@nicksdjohnson @CollinCusce What's the planned solution to achieve load balancing across shards in ETH2?

@clint_ethwood @nicksdjohnson @CollinCusce I believe it'll work the other way: if you're not on the popular shard,  you'll incur additional fees for the complex inter-shard communication you'll need to invoke to access the popular contracts.

If you try to solve your blockchain scalability problem by standard sharding n ways, you will have n+1 problems:
1 popular shard that's just as bad as your original chain, 
n-1 additional problems for each shard, plus 
the inter-shard communication problem. https://t.co/EU41Qxaqsv
@ercwl Just stick to what is true and scientifically backed, and the world will come around. Trust me on this.

@nicksdjohnson @CollinCusce AVA supports sub-networks, which is a form of functional sharding. Gaming contracts have no reason to be on the same subnet as, say, financial contracts. A node in one of those two sub-networks has no need to process any of the other sub-network's transactions.

@nicksdjohnson @CollinCusce But sharding like that creates an incentive to grind through hashes until your contact end up on the same shard as the DAI contract. In the limit, it'd accomplish nothing other than complicating and slowing down the protocol as everyone ends up on the same shard. >>

@nicksdjohnson @CollinCusce One thing we do right now is "functional sharding," in contrast with the standard "random sharding" idea that you see people try to carry over from the database world. Random sharding splits the chain by something like the contract address, which sounds ok at first. >>

@nicksdjohnson @CollinCusce Our current testnet code has the slowest imaginable sync right now. To your higher level point: we will unveil our strategy for addressing unlimited blockchain growth at our mainnet. It's practical and will seem obvious in retrospect, but seems to have eluded other projects. >>

That concludes today's #microlecture. Please use correct terminology, and please test your code. Simplest testing would have caught this.

If I expect to get my money back, and I don't, that's a flaw. It violates their contract with me, the user. It's severe.

If there's some weird unanticipated behavior, it's a bug. 

If an error message has a misspelling, that's a typo.

Typos happen in text. 

Problems that affect execution are "bugs."

Any divergence from a specification are "flaws."

Not all bugs are flaws. Some unexpected behaviors do not affect user expectations.
I always thought the word "bug" was too diminutive. "Flaw" is often more appropriate. I don't understand someone trying to draw a distinction between bug and typo. https://t.co/ri4zqDtMeN

Designing and implementing algorithms.

To a first approximation, most projects reuse existing components. Most projects are just glue. The ability to analyze is used solely as a tool in selecting which preexisting libraries to download. 

Luckily, there are exceptions to this.

Cache conscious data placement.
Tiling.
Stride detection.

Trying to combine these topics with an untyped, interpreted language that executes 1000x slower than normal is like trying to mix water and oil.

Political science. 
Historical accounts of political intrigue and smart people playing 14-D chess.

Turns out that every vote just comes down to "keep things the same" or "burn it to hell and replace it with whatever, as long as it can fog a mirror."

Types.
Compiler Optimizations.
Dataflow analysis.
Peephole optimization.

Blockchains are very resilient or prone to failure. The difference depends not at all on operational skills. In fact, the very idea of "operating" a decentralized chain should be a red flag. What matters is the ability to design self-tending, robust protocols.
Blockchains are fundamentally different. You could be Kakao, or Telegram, and still watch your blockchain falter. Your expertise with datacenters and admins on call is absolutely useless.
My Lesson #2 from the Klaytn outage.\n\nIt doesn't matter who is behind a chain and what kind of experience they have with running centralized services.

The avalanche protocol is different. It's far more robust. Does not require precise agreement on membership. Nodes can disagree on which nodes they believe to be up or down, and still make sound decisions.
So, my Lesson #1 from the Klaytn outage.\n\nThese liveness issues are to be expected with the crop of PoS coins out there that are based on classical protocols.

Classical protocols are fragile, and they also accommodate only a tiny number of participants. (As an aside, that's also why Libra, based on the classical HotStuff protocol co-authored by my student @Tederminant, aspires to have at most 100 validators).
I've heard @VladZamfir mention many times that he fully expects ETH2 to experience liveness problems. This is because ETH2 is based on a classical algorithm, not very different from EOS.
Classical consensus protocols were very well understood when Satoshi was looking to devise an internet scale cryptocurrency. He rejected them because they are all fragile.

Before this, EOS had a similar outage. 

So did Stellar.

The common thread between all these platforms is that they are all based on classical consensus protocols.

Klaytn, the South Korean blockchain project, had an outage that lasted 13 hours.

There are two bits of crucial information here that most mainstream coverage missed and will continue to miss.

Klaytn Blockchain Prevented from Generating Blocks ‚Äî https://t.co/fSbKCwvTR1

Don't give into the doom & gloomers online. Demand a science based policy from politicians. Otherwise follow the sensible measures that every sane country is converging towards. We'll get over this.
There are only 300m Americans. The government has extensive data on all of us. It's not computationally difficult to track the disease on an individual basis.

Follow the actual experts. There's a lot of noise online, backed by a lot of flawed math and flawed reasoning. The actual experts have proper models, where they simulate actual people engaging in real life activities. They can make proper predictions.

My main message is simply to say: do not listen to me or others like me. We lack the credentials/knowledge.

Do not follow the causalty numbers, except as a rough guide. We lack the context.

Do not pay much heed to the online simulators. They lack precision.
I'm just another techbro, albeit one who works on epidemic algorithms, like the Avalanche consensus protocol. These protocols are governed by sigmoids.

It's definitely Not Just Another Flu, but it's also not The End Of The World. It's significant, requires a drastic change in lifestyle, but it's controllable. We know this because we've. observed. it. get. controlled. in. multiple. countries. Just look up at the graph above.
A news channel that recently divided 500m by 317m and somehow managed to get 1.53m as a result is now spreading fear about the virus. Innumeracy is everywhere.

The numbers involved will seem very large, because they are large. But hardly anyone puts them in context. We had one guy predicting that 1.5m will die globally. Ok, but 60m people die globally every year. That number is bad but not that bad, esp given there will be overlap.
There's a reason we have professionals who study public health. There's a reason why we train epidemiologists and don't just hire techbros.
For instance, superspreading occurs at religious congregations, funerals, crowded clubs and the like. Control those, and R0 is reduced drastically.

Do not pay attention to any epidemic models which model R0 as a single number. Infection isn't uniform. We have superspreaders: most people only infect a small number, but some infect large groups, possibly because of certain social interactions. These folks pull the average up.

So that line isn't at 20% (the percentage of severe cases) of 100% of humanity. It's possibly far lower. And with social distancing, contact tracing, extensive testing and quarantine, we can lower it still.
The cruise ship provided an interesting data point: of the 3711 people on board, only 715 got covid-19 at all. Far fewer had the severe form of the illness. The asymptote was fairly low.

What's the maximal percentage of the population that's susceptible to the severe forms of sars-cov2? No one knows. There are quite a few genes that confer protection against related pathogens. Thalassemia trait, blood types, and other genes may well prohibit severe forms of it.
How many of the techbros who opine on this virus actually follow any of this?

As a country increases testing, the number of cases will go up. Sometimes very fast, as they deploy more tests. One cannot interpret the daily numbers unless one compensates for changes in the number of tests administered and testing protocols.

The invisible horizontal line (asymptote) that the sigmoid approaches depends on just two big things:
1. Whether R0 is below 1.
2. The percent of vulnerable population.

But that graph also depends crucially on another:
3. The amount of testing.

Epidemics are sigmoids because the pool of susceptible people dwindles down over time. As the disease infects more people, it becomes increasingly difficult for a sick person to encounter and infect a previously uninfected person.
Look at the number of cases in China, the red line. It's a clear sigmoid. https://t.co/4TExcddcFF

What's a sigmoid function? It's a function that looks like an S that has been slanted to the right. It starts out fast, like an exponential, but then slows down as it approaches an invisible horizontal line.
A lot of people have been modeling the epidemic spread as an exponential. \n\nIt isn't. It's a sigmoid.

@real_y_0 That's exactly the right thing to demand of every new entrant. If the answer is "because my gut tells me so," run away.
Many many early systems fail these checks, PoW and PoS included. The year ahead will drive this point home.

It is essential that (1) protocols admit as many participants as possible, (2) they do not incentivize people pooling their resources, and (3) they do not have centralized points anywhere in protocol or externally.
We will see a series of failures of various altcoins in the next year. We decentralize protocols to avoid these kinds of failures.

A related corollary is that the relative longevity of the founding team matters immensely. If there isn't a community of people dedicated to the health of a system, if a project is being pushed by a bunch of people who just dabble or want to get rich quick, failure is inevitable.
Satoshi was brilliant and had a breakthrough. Since then, we did not have any breakthroughs at the consensus layer until Avalanche came along.
The common thread is that these are early systems, with no technical foundation, based on "design by gut feel" by hobbyists, subject to essentially no scrutiny.

This is not limited to just DPOS. Even as I write this, we have a "stopped blockchain," we had another PoS chain cartelize and then hiccup last week, and we have had countless 51% attacks on PoW with rental hashpower. The common thread among these isn't PoS.

There are many other vulnerable coins out there, based on the same ideas. Worse, there are protocols that people are pushing for future systems that have not been deployed yet but are based on the same highly-limited, highly-centralized infrastructure.

Many of these systems were based on ideas from the 1980s. Academics worked on these systems, their weaknesses were well known, and Satoshi knew about them in 2009. He and everyone else rejected them, because they are inherently fragile.
First, we are now beginning to see failures of weak, fragile blockchains, based on obsolete protocols.
Its failure today is indicative of just two trends, and no more.
It was just an appcoin, with a token whose structure was so complex, almost purposefully so to defy analysis. Everyone at the time cautioned others about the design of this system.
Steemit was one of the first altcoins. Its design was overly complicated. There was zero technical breakthrough that would address the commonly known problems with DPoS.

What is necessary are services where access to such information is not given freely to every Jack and Jill who walks off the street with a padded resume. Where information is secure by default.\n\nThis is why we crypto.

We know from prior whistleblower reports that secret services have information pipelines lined up between each other. All of this info leaks, is routed between various agencies, compiled for eternity.

For instance, people's health records have all kinds of protections associated with them. We enforce these diligently at the doctors' offices with HIPPA (a topic for another time).\n\nBut name me one person who doesn't discuss his health conditions in email/private messages.
Large lists of people routinely have access to private information. Interns and others routinely get access to information they should not have, even by law.
It is the second big threat facing people online.  The first one is the service provider legitimately collecting and selling our information, as with Facebook and Cambridge Analytica.

@ComplicatedIsOK @angela_walch My guess is that this person was referring to atomic broadcast (AB), which sounds like it is only about message transmission (which it involves, but goes beyond), but is really about agreeing on order. AB is equivalent to consensus.

@ComplicatedIsOK @angela_walch No, transmission isn't termed consensus. There's a related concept, called "atomic broadcast," that refers to message transmission to a group where all group members receive the same messages in the same order. It is a specific application of consensus protocols.

People generally attack "premined" coins, because a lot of scammers have dumped their premined coins on the public. But premines are actually a tax-efficient strategy, and any other scheme for giving coins to developers ends up incurring, well, a significant tax.
If instead the coin creator were to set aside some collection of coins at genesis, when coins are cheap, then the tax burden during the project's lifetime would be much better.
These taxable revenues are typically calculated on the price of the coins on the day of creation. So they can be substantial.

Take a scheme such as the BCH proposal or ZCash's founder's reward, where the coinbase provides coins to a developer group. These are new coins that just got minted. Someone needs to pay Uncle Sam (or Uncle Xi, or in any case, some government tax collector).

Today is an appropriate time to visit the topic of "tax efficiency" for developer funds.  \n\nMany coins want to incentivize their developers. The way they give them coins can have significant tax consequences.

Clarification: "attacks due to underfunded devs" really means "attacks that could have been prevented by better funded dev teams." Not attacks by devs themselves, though we've seen suspected insider attacks on certain coins as well.

So, overall, what to make of this:

It's a clever proposal, with good intent. The 6 month sunset clause makes it even better.

But it needs to be debated and made concrete. Any attempt to foreshorten discussion and debate is a terrible idea and sets a bad precedent.

Third and final problem is that there are many underspecified aspects to the proposal. Specifically, who will manage the collected funds and how will they be distributed? This is exactly when some much needed community discussion would have been useful.
The principle of "no debate" is a terrible one. It is antithetical to the crypto ethos.

And this alone is grounds for pressing the pause button. 

It's very clear that this is a proposal in good faith, by people who care about BCH. It's not a bad proposal. 

But the way in which it was sprung up on the community without discussion sets a bad precedent and bad optics

The second, and substantive, problem is the way the proposal came out of nowhere. Springing such a proposal, with orphaning built in, on a community with no prior discussion was terrible PR and community management.

The orphaning will not practically impact any other miners' decisions about which chain to mine on. They will follow their income, and we already discussed how the plan cleverly shifts costs to BTC as long as there's a price/hashrate difference between the tokens.

First, it's coercive on miners. Practically, the orphaning is a way to force Calvin Ayre to pay. There isn't a single person who cares about Calvin, probably not even his mother, assuming she's alive and has seen his pictures from the Caribbean.
But there are three unpalatable aspects to this proposal.

From a practical perspective, it's much better to see devs funded and incentive aligned, than to watch them make protocol changes to divert fees and income to layers they control. And much better to fund them than to watch them use sock puppets to steer their community astray.

From a security perspective, The trade off here is slightly lower hash rate for BCH, in exchange for developer funding. This is sensible: empirically, more attacks have been due to underfunded devs than to malicious hashrate.
From a financial perspective, there's something clever going on: the costs are borne mostly by BTC. This cost-shifting will continue to work as long as BTC is hashrate dominant.

But it's misleading to compare this proposal to the way BTC rammed Segwit via a soft-fork. Segwit was a protocol change visible to the public. This policy redirects miners' income, it does not have any protocol consequences for end users (modulo the issues below).
From a principled perspective, it's highly unusual to enforce compliance with an unpopular proposal through a soft fork.

So, not only does this miner have to go back down to below 50%, but the absolute hash power needs to increase to render his potential hash power on the sidelines to less than ~30%. Let's see when this happens.
The chain becomes safe again only when the absolute amount of hashpower has increased to the point where the attacker's peak hash power is less than 30% or so.
The number of confirmations depends on the size of a potential attacker. If the attacker has more than 50% **deployed or on the sidelines**, no number of confirms is safe.
But this is a terrible sign for the health of the coin. Many people think that if only this miner's percentage goes below 50%, things would become safe again. This is false.

We wouldn't expect this situation to stay like this forever. A smart 51% miner should repurpose her rigs so that (1) she spends as little electricity as possible and drives difficulty down, (2) creates the appearance of a healthy coin.

@VitalikButerin 2. Leader waiting until near-timeout may also create a mess. It's a partial liveness violation, leading to protocol costs. Size of mess depends on synchrony assumption, and cost of view change. \n\nSlashing may help, but needs distributed failure detection, a complex op.

@not_pr0 I'm still a big believer in ETH. Part of what I have always done is point out common fallacies around distributed systems. The topic is complex and many people get it wrong. If you re-read the thread, it's pointing out technical differences, not "shilling" by any stretch.
AVA is leaderless -- anyone can initiate a transaction -- so it's far more robust and does not need slashing.

In particular, EOS/ETH2.0 style protocols have designated leaders, and a misbehaving leader could greatly slow down the operation of the protocol. That is a legitimate reason for deciding to employ slashing.

But there's one issue that @kevinsekniqi is ignoring, due to his focus on Avalanche-style leaderless protocols. \n\nNamely, if your protocol has running time that is dependent on non-byzantine behavior, then slashing may be necessary.

This is a very good point. Bitcoin does not slash miners.  Existence proof that lack of slashing doesn't imply lack of security. https://t.co/HMUps5fkfy

@nicksdjohnson @hasufl Depends on the protocol. You need more stake than the attack threshold, which is 34% for most protocols. The discovery will cause a ding on token price, which is a substantial loss for the 34% attacker.

And slashing is highly undesirable. Hardware, software and system configuration errors can cause people to lose their staked coins. That's pretty unnerving, it'd keep me up at night. At least some of us got into crypto to build calming, predictable technology.

Keep in mind that PoW protocols are typically secured by 1-3% of their market cap in the form of mining hardware. A simple 51% attack requires an expenditure that's half that amount.\n\nIn contrast, most PoS systems require 34% of their total market cap to pull off an attack.
Leaderless protocols, such as Avalanche, are much more robust. This is one of the reasons we do not plan to employ slashing in AVA.
Leader-based consensus protocols are particularly vulnerable to such attacks. Rotating the leader doesn't help, and probably makes it worse.

Take, for example, an EOS-style protocol. If I can engage in shenanigans to screw you over when you're the designated block producer for a given block, but otherwise make progress myself, then slashing is called for.
If a validator can misbehave and cause other validators to incur disproportionate costs that it itself does not face, then slashing is necessary.
Now, there are some scenarios where slashing is useful, and even necessary.

Imagine collecting 34% of the stake to crash Cosmos or ETH2 or another coin based on PoS coupled with a classical consensus protocol.

Imagine succeeding at it.

Oops, your coins are worthless.
In effect, a successful attack is self-slashing.

It's a common error to only consider "in-game" economics, and ignore "externalities." In game, you have the same number of your coins after a successful attack. In the external world, they are worthless.
A validator that successfully attacks the network will see the value of her stake decline substantially.
This is incorrect and illustrates a common fallacy in the analysis of cryptocurrencies. https://t.co/MeJbZWaaYz

All ideas on how to make SV tech companies understand their responsibilities to a very very large global audience are welcome.
Recall that, for years, every instant message on Facebook revealed your location, with great precision, to whomever you messaged. I'm confident people got killed as a result of that feature.

I'm not sure how to train the right kind of thinking.\n\nBut I'm 1000% sure that we do not, and I'm just as sure that the vast majority of PMs at major tech firms see the world through a comfortable SV lens that is quite cavalier about data leaks to friends.

What's the takeaway? 

Writing software at that scale requires a different kind of diligence, empathy, understanding, and anticipation.

What seems inconsequential to a valley engineer might be a life or death matter to someone in, say, Riyadh or whatever else.
We heard so much about "Google scale." \n\nAt Google/Facebook scale, someone *will* get hurt.

But this kind of casual leak **can and will get people killed**. There are jealous husbands (and maybe wives, too, but the stats are skewed) out there who will go in a rage instead of debugging that it was caused by a bad Bluetooth association and a misfeature plus data leak.

This bug might seem like a no big deal. A PM at Google writes it up as a cutesy feature. Given the huge amount of privacy sensitive data Google collates and sells, it feels like nothing to have Android Auto leak what you're doing to your friends.

1. He wasn't driving right then.

2. He wasn't supposed to be driving right then.

3. He didn't explicitly authorize Android Auto to send Signal messages.

4. Android Auto revealed his activities to a large number of people

5. Worse, it was wrong, due to a Bluetooth pairing.

Someone sent an message to one of our Signal groups this morning, and one of our engineers immediately responded with "I'm driving right now."

Closer inspection revealed that Android Auto sent this on his behalf.

There's are a couple of problems with this.
A short thread about Privacy, Silicon Valley Tech, and unintended consequences of software designed by people who do not appreciate the scale of deployment.

This exemption would align the incentives of all the parties. Faced with the risk of being held liable, the service providers would suddenly develop algos for detecting malicious or deeply harmful content.

A simple fix that would completely change the Internet is to grant immunity **only when the service provider is not actively monetizing the content**. If Facebook is using the content to show ads, it's partly complicit in the harm arising from the content itself.

A critical aspect of this that many have overlooked so far is that FB, Google and others take active steps to monetize user-generated content. They actively profit off of users' activities, promote them blindly, and hide behind Section 230 when the going gets rough.
Tech companies are increasingly under fire for not considering the societal harms that they cause, and this law which insulates them from such harm is going to increasingly come under fire.

Overall, episodes like this remind us all why protocol design is **absolutely essential**. People will, and constantly do, try to game vulnerabilitirs in system design. The protocols used are not all the same, and some are inherently more centralized and less secure than others.
And not surprisingly, people will game the system by pretending to be N different people. That's what we allegedly saw here.

Protocols where an existing small group of validators vote to select entrants into that tiny group are subject to cabal formation. The rewards that go solely to those nodes provide an incentive for the group to turn into an exclusive club.
@ManuelPolavieja Nodes actively involved in block creation/selection, so not full nodes. In the EOS context, I am referring to BPs.

There is only one protocol family that does scale well in the number of active participants, and that's the recently unveiled Avalanche protocol. It can support thousands to millions of actively participating validators, without committee subselection.

That's why you see blockchain designs where there are large pools of validators, and there are constructs like "random beacons" and "committee subselection." It's because older protocols do not scale well in the number of active participants and need to create small groups.

To put centralization in EOS in perspective: \n\n21 is a tiny number, but all blockchains based on Classical and Nakamoto protocols suffer from such small numbers. There isn't a single existing system that can handle more than 100 active participants.
Finally, EOS relies on a relatively tiny number of BPs. 21 is a pretty small, and therefore a pretty vulnerable, number.

Second, EOS has only 21, far too few, block producers (BPs), which makes attacks like this devastating. Compromising a third (that is 7 of 21) of the BPs/miners can cause security violations for most blockchains, and is not to be taken lightly. This attack came close.

First, EOS relies on human processes for sybil control, in contrast with Bitcoin's electricity consuming POW or the PoS solutions used by recent chains. Human processes are inherently fragile. Their recovery will also involve much human bickering and fighting.
This is a simple Sybil attack. And the whole episode shows three serious failures.

I'm sure people on Twitter, where new accounts with fake names spring up daily, appreciate the differences between the two kinds of anon. The key differentiator is "is this person anon for a societally good aim, or are they using anonymity as a shield while they attack others?"

In contrast, a bad use of anonymity is when people create cheap, throwaway identities to launch attacks on others without repercussions. Far from paying a price, they are using anonymity to shield themselves and make others pay costs for refuting their attacks.

This enables us to consider the tech independent of its creator. And he paid the ultimate price for this: he gets no credit for what was, at the time, a big invention. Yes, he was anonymous, and **he used that anonymity for a constructive purpose**, not to escape scrutiny.
Another good use of anonymity is exemplified by Satoshi. He gave a gift to the world, and committed the ultimate selfless act: he kept himself out of the picture.

One good use of anonymity is a high school student or young adult, exploring a topic, like STDs. They should be able to do this without repercussions from family and teachers. Their ISP shouldn't out their interests by showing them or their family members targeted ads.
But there are good and bad uses of anonymity. The core technology that enables one also enables the other. So we need social measures to push back on bad uses.

Many people, especially in the boomer generation that did not grow up with the internet, want to prohibit this. We hear ideas as dumb as "drivers licenses for the internet." These are terrible ideas and we need privacy technologies to enable people to have online anonymity.
First of all, anonymity is essential online. People experiment with and explore all kinds of topics online. They should be able to do this without risking their hard-earned reputation.
There's a lot of confusion about identity and anonymity, even in cypherpunk circles. So this is a thread about good uses of anonymity versus bad.

As a result, every trade on a current DEX involves an implicit option. You're not just paying for the asset, you are also paying for the implicit option, granted to one side because atomic swaps are asymmetric. This means that #DeFi DEXs will always offer worse prices to one side

Current DEXs rely on atomic swap primitives that have a time bound. This, in turn, enables one of the participants to see if the trade is developing in their favor during that time bound, and abort the swap. \n\nIn essence, Bob has been granted an option!
Currently listening to a very interesting paper that describes a fundamental problem with current DEXs that explains why they will offer worse execution compared to external, centralized markets.

1. Consensus protocol
2. EVM implementation
3. EVM computational model
4. Inherent serialization in smart contracts
5. The computational capacity of a single node

Bottom line is that BTC mining is extremely centralized. Most of it is manufactured by one company. It's mostly in one country. The mining game causes the miner with the lowest capex to overtake others. It's just decentralization theater.

But what's damning here isn't anything technical.\n\nIt's the community: the BTC thought leaders are mostly coin shilling clowns. The few BTC code janitors who inherited Satoshi's code base hide behind them, never once correcting their aberrant behavior.
You all know about the block size, and how it's outdated.\n\nNow you know about the block interval, and how it inherently gives rise to false positives.

Underneath Samson's "nothing to see here, really, just look at this other graph where we averaged everything out and made the anomaly disappear" narrative lies abject fear. \n\nBTC is ancient technology. Many of its parameters are badly chosen.

Bitcoin developers keep making a lot of noise about how they always target the worst case scenario, when doing so suits the aims of the VC exit scam and apparel company. When there's some inconvenient truth, they try to pretend it's the best case and resort to personal attacks.

There was a critical teachable moment here: 

Exchanges need to monitor the blockchain and adjust the confirmation time in response to sudden loss of hash rate. 

You don't know why that hash disappeared, and it's not safe to continue with 6 confirms.

Because of the long interblock times, false positive alerts are just a fact of Bitcoin life, *assuming that the problem was statistical variation*. Of course, no one actually knows that, least of all, an internet clown.

This means that everyone has to monitor the blockchain and detect attacks *within 5 blocks*, ideally earlier. \n\nOnly a moron would suggest using a running average of 2016 blocks to examine the hash rate. You'd detect attacks 2011 blocks too late.

But the root problem is that Satoshi picked a very long interblock interval. 10 minutes is a long time. Bitcoin has to pick that number generously because it's a synchronous protocol. This then yields a finalization time of 6 blocks, 1 hour. Exchanges have 6 blocks hardwired.

*Of course*, if you average a lot of data points together, you can make *any* anomaly disappear. \n\nGuess what the maxis are doing? They are claiming that we should be averaging lots of blocks together, because reasons.

The maxis are clinging onto the claim that it was "just" a statistical anomaly. Samson isn't a mathematician, he's the chief meme officer at a company that has no products, no CTO. His expertise is sock puppets and personal attacks to cover up for the VC exit scam of his company.

No one knows what actually happened to the Bitcoin hash rate.

Could be software configuration errors at a miner 

Could be a mining facility that went down. 

Last time, it was hydro problems in China.

Samson has no idea. He's just asserting that it was a statistical anomaly.

@francispouliot_ @hcarpach 1. All correlated failures are bad.

2. Best case, it's a dozen or so miners. Worst case, one person. No one knows the exact count.

3. Bitcoiners pretend to plan for the worst case, when it serves their goals, but then go YOLO when it's convenient.

Cheers.

Simple exercise: suppose you see 51% of the hashrate disappear. What should you do? Stop accepting payments 

What about 49%? Number of confirmations should be INFINITY. 

48%? Thousands of blocks. 

40-something? Hundreds.

You get the idea. 6 isn't a magic number.

The number of confirmations Satoshi calculated in the whitepaper, 6, isn't some magic number. It's based on an assumption that the attacker has at most 30% of the hashrate. \n\nIf >30% of the hashrate suddenly disappears, exchanges should up the number of confirmations required.

@deadalnix I was concerned about a simple reorg, not SM. We would see a single, sudden change of the suffix of the blockchain, and exchanges would lose funds in the attack. There'd be no warning. Which is why exchanges should up the number of confirms when hashrate drops.

@deadalnix Number of confirmations recommended by Satoshi, 6, isn't magic. It's based on an assumption that the attacker's hashrate is 30% or lower.\n\nSimple exercise: if the attacker has 49% of the hashpower, # of confirms should be INFINITY.

@j8k3b @Cornell Very much so.
The more active a researcher is, the more disproportionately they are affected. If you run a lab or if you travel to conferences, expect to pay substantial overhead, in time and money.

There's always some idiot somewhere, almost invariably a doctor in some medical school, that abuses the system. The admins then institute more and more onerous rules that detract from the core mission, and push costs to academics.

The administrators at a university, at least my university, have zero incentive to streamline any process other than submitting grants. Reimbursements are a nightmare. I used to subsidize Cornell University out of my paycheck by $10k - $20k.

Companies have a profit motive. At the end of the day, they want you to get your work done and get reimbursed. So they generally have evolved practices that aren't terrible. At Ava Labs, we use Brexx. Employees have cards that charge directly to accounts. It works beautifully.

Employers make it difficult to get reimbursements. The real reason for this is a system that  rewards pushing operational costs to employees. And nowhere is the practice more abusive than at universities. https://t.co/FxmlWEJWZq

The best defense against overeager lawmakers is a healthy community, with lots of use cases and positive outcomes, and people with credentials singing the praises of societal change to come.

When the push comes to shove, the noisemakers on social media, the losers who post daily bromides, the "whales," pump-and-dump group operators, and the like have zero pull and zero power. They can't help. If invited, they'd be an embarrassment.

@mrauchs The miner with the lowest cost of electricity will, over time, become the sole miner. This isn't something I saw SN discuss.

Overall, the world is a different place than it was in 2009. It's a testament to SN that his tech is still around. The original question asked about changes to miner game theory and SN's assumptions. I chronicled the ways in which the original ideas have had to be modified.

Ok 9. SN did not seem to consider the inherent centralization of industrial scale mining. Mining rig manufacture, access to rigs, and access to cheap electricity are inherently limited. This leads towards a small set of industrial miners.
Oh, let's not forget:\n8. SN seemed not to foresee just how much energy would be spent on mining, and how much value would leak out of the system to the power companies. That changes the dynamic.

Some of these attacks may not arise in practice. Some are fixable. But the original question asked how the incentives are different from what SN foresaw in 2009. This is my quick summary of how the world has evolved.

7. Satoshi did foresee, but was wrong on, what happens when transaction fees exceed block rewards. He indicated that the system would operate as normal. This is incorrect, as miners have an incentive to snipe each other's transactions instead of collaboratively building a chain.

6. Finally, people are layering applications on top of the chain, eg Omni and LN. If miners are in bed with attackers on these systems, the dynamics change. E.g. LN can be attacked via censorship. If Omni holds more value than block rewards, the mining dynamics are different.

5. Satoshi's famous "6 block" confirmation calculation assumes a relatively small percentage of attacker hashpower. As the amount of available rental hash and attacker budget changes, it needs to be recalculated.\n\nIf a pow attacker has 49%, # of confirms required is infinity.

4. Hash rental markets make temporary attacks possible. These did exist in 2009, became unfeasible with the shift to ASICs, and are once again a possibility. We saw hash rental markets used, in conjunction with some of the other points above, to attack BTG.

3. Satoshi only considered a world where there's a single coin. When multiple coins share the same hash function, the dynamics are different. Hashwars, difficulty raising attacks, and death spirals are example attacks from this domain.

2. Satoshi did not explicitly mention pools. That changes the game theory substantially, especially if the miners within a pool are not checking the work of the pool operator. A single bad actor can rope in honest-but-not-tech-savvy actors into a byzantine attack.

1. We now know that selfish mining is a possibility against PoW coins. 51% honesty isn't sufficient -- depending on the coin, 66% to 100% need to be honest.\n\nLuckily, most miners have been honest so far, but the threat is ever present, esp for low hashrate coins.
There have been several fundamental changes to the incentives in Bitcoin since its launch. https://t.co/4YK0DEEPhH

@angela_walch @skwp There's a fundamental assumption that the miners are independent entities whose primary income is from coins. If miners were to be in bed with, say, an application layered on top of Bitcoin, they might have an incentive to launch attacks, like censorship and reverting the chain.
@nicksdjohnson @angela_walch That's incorrect. At least 66% need to be honest, perhaps more. https://t.co/Rha7mkhYJA

@nicksdjohnson I'm making up the numbers instead of calculating them as I'm at the beach, so they are for illustrative purposes, but you get the idea. \n\nI hope these point out how Avalanche differs from classical systems, which are incredibly fragile.

@nicksdjohnson Suppose you configure Avalanche to tolerate 20% Byzantine attackers. That is, the likelihood of a safety violation is very low, say once in 20,000 years, as long as attacker <20%.\n\nSuppose now that the attacker is 25%. What now?

@nicksdjohnson Avalanche can be configured to withstand any Byzantine fraction <50% with both safety and liveness guarantees. Even better, it gets more efficient the lower the expected Byzantine fraction is. \n\nIt's the only protocol family with this property that I know of.

@nicksdjohnson Avalanche can resist >50% Byzantine attacker. It cannot guarantee liveness in this scenario, but it guarantees safety.\n\nI'm not aware of other efficient protocols that can do the same.
@nicksdjohnson As for the failure threshold:\n\nAvalanche is unique in how strong it is when it comes to the Byzantine failure threshold. Let me expand on this since you introduced it.

@petkodp My quick response:

1. Avalanche can prune its DAG to drop spent UTXOs, which can alleviates storage costs

2. Avalanche can gossip at the full speed of the network, whereas Bitcoin leaves the wire idle.

3. Like sharding, a DAG helps build decisions in parallel.

RT @el33th4xor: I believe many ICOs raised far more than their worth. But this franken-toothbrush shows that there's still lots of money ch‚Ä¶

@jgharris7 Of course. We know this from Enron and Theranos and the countless scams before them. The question is: what do we need to do now in order for worthwhile efforts to be funded while scams are kept to a minimum? The thread points out that there just aren't enough good efforts.

@thomas_quinlan @VentureBeat Indeed, brushing is great. But being spied upon is not. \n\nAdding $6 of smarts to a brush to help someone track *themselves* is great. Raising $55m to report people's intimate habits to third parties is not.

Overall, ICOs were just a symptom of a much larger problem. That problem cannot be regulated away. And we have weekly reminders that the traditional finance world is failing to deliver what people demand.

Regulators cannot clamp down on all the disruptive platforms in order to drive people to spybrushes, medical payment processor stocks and Coca-Cola shares. There's a big crowd of people who have already voted with their feet and wallets that the system isn't serving their needs.
One internal issue is that the first generation of coins was nowhere near ready to deliver the dream they promised. We'll sort that out, we know how to build better systems now.

You cannot regulate social movements into compliance. Not in the long term.\n\nYou cannot force people to drop their dream of disruption and put their money into an incremental juice squeezer or a spybrush.

Evidently, people are seeking to finance alternatives, no matter how risky, to the current set of investment opportunities. They are seeking to find efforts that have higher risks but much higher ability to disrupt. In short, they are sick and tired of the old drek.

Were ICOs excessive? Certainly.\nWere many ICOs scams destined to fail? Most definitely.\nBut despite all this, people threw their money at them. If we don't understand the root causes, we can't effectively fix the problem.

Crypto represents an upending of these paradigms. It promises (regardless of whether it can deliver) an end to many incumbents, a flat playing field, and new business models. That's why young folks are excited by it: because it disrupts a system that has run out of ideas.

No wonder that young people, almost always the canaries in the coal mine, are balking at this. Do you want to finance this spy-toothbrush? Can Silicon Valley interest you in a juice squeezer instead? Why don't you play?

The system wants and needs everyone to save, and it offers Amtrak shares and Berkshire-Hathaway. What passes for high tech is really spying on people and showing them ads, or calling cabs for people while lying to them about how many cabs are nearby.
Quick check: name a company that really excites you, without mentioning Tesla or Space-X.

Right now, that problem looks like a combination of intellectual malaise + lack of creativity + incumbents with government protection + big companies sitting on giant cash reserves instead of investing them. End result: there are few good investment opportunities.

Sometimes, there's a problem with the zeitgeist, the state of the world. These issues are typically coupled with a demographic shift. We often fail to analyze the root cause of the problem, and chase down some of the symptoms.

I believe many ICOs raised far more than their worth. But this franken-toothbrush shows that there's still lots of money chasing dumb ideas in the fiat world.\n\nBeam raises $55 million for a connected toothbrush that lowers dental premiums https://t.co/jQZ1l2axyP via @VentureBeat

At any given time, there are people writing papers full of mumbojumbo, filled with technical terms that touch every topic. \n\nEvery time there's a genuine breakthrough, some of these people pop up, note a similar phrase between their gibberish and the breakthrough & claim credit.
